availability.p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

div.head: 19.1.1881 Mittwoch
div.p:
We started from Paris at 7.15 and at 12.30 were at Arras here we took in workmen who walked before the train and cleared away the snow as we went we halted at every station: such as S t Omer, Lens at this last station the workmen got out and went away We also stopped ¾ of an hour on account of snow at 4.20 we were at the station Calais and at 5.30 we were at the end of the pier. We all got on board ship. The sky was very dark and as we got out of port the ship began to roll so that one could not stand without holding on as it grew darker it grew rougher all at once there is the command „Halte“ everybody rushes to one side of the ship and there we see a ship, a wreck with all its masts gone everything gone except its carcase and at its fron a red light darkly illuminating the people on board her. being towed by another ship very nearly equally bad Our sailors scream out for her name the answer is „252 Dunkerque“ At last we see the Dover lights come up on the horizont and at quarter to 9 the „Petrel“ is there. Part of the Pier is washed away and so we have to walk in the bitterest cold up the pier to the station carrying our hand luggage as there are no porters to be had and whats more the pier is dangerous and there is a place where it is hardly 2½ yards wide. At last at the end of the pier I got a porter. But I had lost my party and M r
and M rs Kamintsky. At 7½ we start from Dover from where I had previously sent a telegram to grandmama Lynch, Caroline saying I had arrived in Dover. At 9 minutes to ten we arrive in London after 15 hours journey. The Kamintzkys go on to their ship and I and one of our party M r Samuels got a cab or rather a greengrocers cart who agrees for 12 shillings to drive us home me 140 Westbourne terrace and M r Samuels 80 Lancaster road. I also met Rogers Grandmamma’s coachman at the station. London looks very curious in its white cloak of snow which has in some places drifted up to 6 feet high. We saw one poor girl being picked up frozen and another crowd probably on the same account. At last we arrive and I am glad to get home and go to bed
